dataset.title: Seasonal Dynamics of Soil Microbial Biomass in Coastal Sand Dune Forest

creator.organizationName: Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago

address.deliveryPoint: 6001 W. Pershing Road, Cicero, IL 60804, USA

abstract.para: Sand dunes are a typical landscape in the coast of western Taiwan, where Casuarina forests were established decades ago to stabilize sand dunes and protect the inland vegetation. Study of microbial biomass in such an ecosystem may give insights into the role of microbes in soil fertility and nutrient cycling in vegetation establishment. We delineated our study sites into two topographic units based on elevation and drainage types: upland and lowland. The study lasted for two years, and soil samples were collected every three months. Microbial biomass C (Cmic) and N (Nmic) were high in a shallow humic layer that rested on top of the soil (1222-1319 mg kg-1 for Cmic and 245-276 mg kg-1 for Nmic) and declined sharply to only one-tenth of the above values in the underlying surface soil (0-10 cm depth). Microbial biomass Cmic and Nmic in humic and surface soil were not significantly different between upland and lowland sites. In the upland soils, the mean microbial biomass C was highest in autumn for both the humic and surface soil, and lowest in spring and summer for the humic layer and summer for the surface soil layer. In the lowland soils, the biomass C was highest in winter for both humic and surface soil, and lowest in spring and autumn for the humic layer and spring and summer for surface soil. Strong fluctuations of Cmic and Nmic were associated with the soil moisture prior to sampling, which appeared to control the size of microbial biomass in this environment. Temperature had little effect on the dynamics of soil microbial biomass in the sand dune forest ecosystem.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: The study was performed in a coastal Casuarina forest at Houlong (latitude 24o39' N, longitude 120o47' E), Miaoli in northwestern Taiwan with a typical warm (28.6 oC on average) and wet summer, and a mild (16.3 oC on average) and dry winter.

section.title: Microbass N, C analysis
section.para: Samples of the humic layer (top 2-3 cm), which lies on the surface of soil, were collected from 50 x 50 cm quadrats after carefully removing the undecomposed litter. The soils beneath the humic layer were then sampled at two soil depths (0-10 cm and 10-20 cm) with a soil auger that was 4.25 cm in diameter. Roots and litter were manually removed prior to sieving through a 2 mm sieve. Samples were kept at 4 oC in the dark. Biochemical analyses, including microbial biomass, were completed within two months. Sub-samples were air-dried and ground for analysis of physico-chemical properties.

samplingDescription.para: The study period covered two years starting from January 2002 to October 2003, and sampling was performed at three-month intervals. The sampling sites were the same for all sampling months.
